Setting Up A Sass Project

This project will serve as a template/setup for future Sass projects. I'm going to use Node Sass. The following are the steps I took:

  1. Create a package.json file by typing
    npm init in the terminal
  2. Install Node-Sass Module by typing
    npm install node-sass in terminal
  3. Setup Node-Sass so that it works:
    Create a script to compile the Sass. Open package.json file, and change test to sass in the scripts object. Change the script object to look like this:
    4. from
    "scripts": { "test": "echo \"Error: no test specified\" && exit 1" },
    to
    "scripts": { "sass": "node-sass -w scss/ -o dist/css/ --recursive" },
  4. Test it by typing npm run sass in the terminal

    5. NOTE: After I've added the above to the main.scss file, and then go to my terminal and run npm run sass, a new folder called css will get auto generated inside the existing dist folder and it contains a new file named main.css This new file will get the compiled css loaded into it.

    NOTE: Nothing will happen because I haven't added any Sass yet and I haven't added the link to the compiled css css/main.css in the head of my HTML file. So...

  5. Go to main.scss file and write some Sass:
    -- $primary-color: #003760;

    body {
      background: $primary-color;
      color: #fff;
    }

    NOTE: If you look at your webpage in the browser, it should now be whatever color you chose.

  6. Go back to HTML file and include the link to css/main.css

    7. NOTE: If I go back to dist/css/main.css and look, it now has the compiled Sass!

So to quickly sum up the steps:

  1. Create package.json file with
    npm init
  2. Install node-sass with
    npm install node-sass
  3. Create a script to run the sass
  4. Use VSCode extension "Live Server" to open the index.html file in the browser
  5. Go to main.scss file and write some Sass
  6. Go to index.html and include link to compiled css. Use css/main.css path
  7. Look at the instant results in the browser window!

Last Step

Get it on git. In the terminal type in:

  1. git init
  2. read what it says
  3. git status
  4. notice the feed back is red
  5. git add .
  6. The above means to add all the files in your current directory to git. (THE PERIOD INCLUDED!!!)
  7. git status again
  8. notice the feed back is now green
  9. git commit   -m ' your message '
    If on Windows, use double quotes instead of single, it might help!
